author: chris2_2_2
content: Since it‚Äôs likely a few eth 2.0 pools will rugpull or get hacked is there a chance there will be a dao style fork or is that impossible now?

author: chris2_2_2
content: In the early days it‚Äôs entirely foreseeable to see a 10-20% loss rate among validators

author: chris2_2_2
content: It would be good to have an insurance fund validator pools could pay into üòÖ

author: trent_vanepps
content:
it's ~~impossible~~ very very unlikely, verging on impossible. it opens a can of worms for which necessitates a system of review and correction for any lost/ stolen funds which would become incredibly complex

also diminishes the non-interventionist stance that has been nurtured in the years following the DAO hack

author: trent_vanepps
content: we've already seen unfortunate losses from staking services

author: pietjepuk
content:
Not like I'm the one making decisions or anything, but I would say that while the beaconchain is still in its isolated environment, hard forks to restore bugs on it is an option. That's because it doesn't mess with the economic activity on the EL. Not sure about rugpulls though.
After the merge, I'd say it's almost certain nothing would happen in such a scenario (judging by e.g. EIP-999).

Adding to that, I would say that quite a few parties offering custodial staking services have already done so for many years for other coins, and/or are an exchange having access to much more funds than just what is staked on Ethereum (say Kraken, Binance and Coinbase). If they were to rugpull, I'd say they would have done so already.

author: pietjepuk
content: (not advocating the use of custodial staking services by the way; solo staking is the way to go üòâ )

author: trent_vanepps
content:
the low probability of irregular state changes shouldn't preclude flexpool or other operators from considering a collective insurance fund, it's an interesting idea

though it would be hard to verify some situations eg. "i've lost these private keys" - you can't prove a negative like that. there's also the governance overhead of managing claims which makes me think we won't see anything like this soon

author: ajsutton
content: The network is not here for validators, the validators are here for the network (and are paid for their services).  Validators losing money because they don't do their job properly is exactly how PoS is supposed to work. If we bail them out we unermine the security of the chain. So no, I would never expect a bail out for validators.

author: chris2_2_2
content: 32 made sense back when eth was $400 but now that it‚Äôs 10x it‚Äôs hard to offer secure non custodial staking.

author: chris2_2_2
content: It‚Äôs impossible for any setup that cares about security to offer custodial staking on validation when  its really new and still immature/not compete

author: chris2_2_2
content: And I completely expect some major staking pools to fail. Mt gox was a great example and they it was a lot less complicated to secure it.

author: chris2_2_2
content: Collective insurance does seem attractive but also it‚Äôs hard to ensure given that 100% is like 10-20 years of staking fees

author: pietjepuk
content:
Not going to argue that 32 ETH is a lot now. I agree that we need more things like Rocket Pool, SSV, and changes to the protocol to bring the barrier to entry down where possible.
I also expect some services to fail in some ways or another (some already have lost _some_ funds due to slashable offenses as Trent said). I personally would say that's the price you pay / risk you take when using custodial services. If you can provide an insured option at a premium, that's great for those interested in such a thing.
